If people don't mind, I'm going to request that we hold off on merging things touching datetimelike stuff till we get this in. It's not been a fun morning trying to get this merged on top of master properly.
@jbrockmendel I've tagged some failures with `TODO-ops`. Haven't had a chance to look at them.

> If people don't mind, I'm going to request that we hold off on merging things touching datetimelike stuff till we get this in.

Sounds good.  FWIW the last of my major PRs went in yesterday.  All that's left is the reductions and #24123.

Which of these is correct?

```python
In [3]: list(pd.core.arrays.DatetimeArrayMixin(np.array(['2000-01-01T06:00:00'], dtype='M8[ns]'), dtype=pd.core.dtypes.dtypes.DatetimeTZDtype(tz='US/Central')))
Out[3]: [Timestamp('2000-01-01 06:00:00-0600', tz='US/Central')]
```

as of 2643721fdd66f11fd91dc245ef200ba792836c56 that was


```python
In [3]: list(pd.core.arrays.DatetimeArrayMixin(np.array(['2000-01-01T06:00:00'], dtype='M8[ns]'), dtype=pd.core.dtypes.dtypes.DatetimeTZDtype(tz='US/Central')))
Out[3]: [Timestamp('2000-01-01 00:00:00-0600', tz='US/Central')]
```

On master it's `[Timestamp('2000-01-01 06:00:00-0600', tz='US/Central')]` as well, so going to assume that master is correct...
I'm having a lot of trouble with the constructors right now. What's the recommended way to create a new DatetimeArray/TimedeltaArray/PeriodArray from an array of their underlying data?

> What's the recommended way to create a new DatetimeArray/TimedeltaArray/PeriodArray from an array of their underlying data?

Focusing on the DatetimeArray with non-None tz (which should be isomorphic to passing dtype=Datetime64TZDtype(...)):

- `DatetimeArray(i8_data, tz=tz)` treats the `i8_data` as unix timestamps, i.e. UTC
- `DatetimeArray(M8ns_data, tz=tz)` treats the `M8_data` as _wall times_ in the given tz
- float64 behaves like M8[ns], but I'm pretty sure that is unintentional and so will be deprecated and changed to behave like int64

> Focusing on the DatetimeArray with non-None tz

The different behaviour of integers vs datetime64 is very confusing IMO, and personally I would try to clean that up here, to the extent possible (at least for the DatetimeArray constructor, for DatetimeIndex we can probably leave as that and clean up / deprecate later). 

For the DatetimeArray constructor, we could simply restrict to accepting M8 data as UTC (so not wall times), so exactly the data that is stored? (and unpacking containers that already have that, as we did for PeriodArray) That would IMO make the code a lot easier to read as it is clear what the values need to be when passed to DatetimeArray.

(note: commenting here without already taken a thorough look at the code / diff, I should probably do that first)

> The different behaviour of integers vs datetime64 is very confusing IMO, and personally I would try to clean that up here,

I *think* that's what messed me up yesterday. Thinks like DatetimeArray.copy() were failing with an invalid frequency when a DST boundary was crossed. Previously an `isinstance(datetimearray, DatetimeIndex)` converted the M8 to i8, but that condition isn't true anymore.

I'd recommend waiting on looking through the full diff until later today.

Still not quite ready. I'm going to

1. fixup the `.where`-related changes from #24114 
2. do a pass to clean up cruft
3. rewrite the summary of changes from the initial post

Will ping when that's ready.

Alrighty this should be in a reviewable state (still a WIP though).

There's some unrelated changes `Block.where`. pending the decision on https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24114#issuecomment-445313499 `(small hack for now, or proper support for EA.where)`, we'll have a proper fix and those changes will disappear from the diff.

Going to put up a small summary later (probably tomorrow morning).
I'll take a look.  Are there any pieces likely to be rebased away or separated into stand-alone PRs?

Thanks.

> Are there any pieces likely to be rebased away or separated into stand-alone PRs?

If you identify any candidates, let me know and I'll see what can be done. But I think we're close to the essential changes if we want to take a direct step from where we are to "standalone Datetime/TimedeltaArray".

Started a JSON branch at https://github.com/TomAugspurger/pandas/compare/disown-tz-only-rebased...TomAugspurger:disown-tz-only-rebased+json?expand=1. That fixes the ValueError we were raising, but the serialized data isn't correct.

0a8ccfde0ca58be377c9cda3413a195b69a5eb71 has a hacky fix for the groupby resample test that was failing. Some context, that may help someone more familiar with the groupby code (@WillAyd?, @jreback?) come up with a better solution:

In `_libs/reduction.pyx`, we directly manipulate the index data in a few places (e.g. https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/72d436d4506da82b29afff7e3e07ed9843e52c56/pandas/_libs/reduction.pyx#L268https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/72d436d4506da82b29afff7e3e07ed9843e52c56/pandas/_libs/reduction.pyx#L268 and https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/72d436d4506da82b29afff7e3e07ed9843e52c56/pandas/_libs/reduction.pyx#L595-L598), and do stuff with the strides and sizes of the buffer that I don't really understand. Anyway, that stuff only works for indexes where `Index._data` is an ndarray.

The most obvious fix, which doesn't really require updating `_libs/reduction.pyx` is to just use a new attribute like `_index_data` (bad name) for getting / setting the actual data backing an index. For most classes this would be a reference to `Index._data`. For datetimelike, it's a reference to `index._data._data`. That change fixes the test, but feels inelegant. Any suggestions on how it could be improved?

With 0a8ccfde0ca58be377c9cda3413a195b69a5eb71 in, the xfails are down to a the ops ones (xfailed with `TODO-ops`), a few pickle ones (`TODO-pickle`), and a few JSON ones (`TODO-json`). I'm probably going to tackle the JSON ones first.

edit: No progress on JSON stuff. Moving on to pickle.

We officially have our first passing build :) Py2 is failing hard though. It seems that `indexes/datetimelike.py::wrap_array_method` won't work anymore

```python
TypeError: unbound method tz_localize() must be called with DatetimeArrayMixin instance as first argument (got DatetimeIndex instance instead)
```

Previously that worked since DatetimeIndex was a subclass of DatetimeArray.

Edit: fixing this by delegating with, e.g. `DatetimeDelegateMixin`.

All the pickle issues are (hopefully) addressed.

Back to JSON.

doesn't seem to work.

558adf8871e98af85a3f9f6085fb1d0466292085 has the first batch of the JSON changes. I'm not proposing that as a good example for what the JSON IO interface should be for 3rd parties, just something to get the tests (mostly) passing.

There are still some failures I haven't figured out yet (marked with xfail(reason="TODO-JSON")`)

The remaining JSON failure looks like the following

```python
In [8]: df1 = pd.DataFrame({"A": pd.date_range('2000', periods=4)})

In [9]: df2 = pd.DataFrame({"A": pd.date_range('2000', periods=4, tz="UTC")})

In [10]: df1.to_json()
Out[10]: '{"A":{"0":946684800000,"1":946771200000,"2":946857600000,"3":946944000000}}'

In [11]: df2.to_json()
Out[11]: '{"0":946684800000,"1":946771200000,"2":946857600000,"3":946944000000}'
```

`Out[10]` is correct. `Out[11] is missing the outer key for the column names.


https://github.com/TomAugspurger/pandas/compare/disown-tz-only-rebased...TomAugspurger:disown-tz-only-rebased+json?expand=1 has some debugging modifications, in case anyone more familiar with the code than me has a chance to look.

Going to unxfail the ops stuff now.

Looks like I have some 32-bit failures too: https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=5131

Got most of the ops xfails in c3b7dea0a26b2b4543b2ba0d0ef303d888e929af. Turned out I was overwriting the TDI dispatching with the usual index dispatch mechanism, instead of dispatching to TDA like we do on master.

@jbrockmendel @jreback is it intentional that `Period/DatetimeIndex` ignore integer sign and size in `.astype`?

```python
In [1]: import pandas as pd

In [2]: pd.period_range('2000', periods=4).astype('int32')
Out[2]: Int64Index([10957, 10958, 10959, 10960], dtype='int64')

In [3]: pd.date_range('2000', periods=4).astype('int32')
Out[3]:
Int64Index([946684800000000000, 946771200000000000, 946857600000000000,
            946944000000000000],
           dtype='int64')
```

Perhaps I added the failing test in https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/466824994#L2353

Edit: this is an inconsistency between PeriodIndex.astype and PeriodArray.astype on master, that this PR fixed as part of the refactor. I'll proceed under the assumption that we want those to be consistent (ignore sign and size) and we can deprecate things later if we want.

@TomAugspurger about https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24024#issuecomment-446575390

yes, we don't have an int32 Index to back this with, so no choice here. In theory we *should* allow this, but I think would cause quite a lot of work / test breakage for not a lot of gain.

Do people have thoughts on the return value of `Series[datetime64[ns, tz]].unique()`

On master, return an ndarray of Timestamp objects.

Right now, this PR returns a DatetimeAray:

```python
In [3]: pd.Series(pd.date_range('2000', periods=2, tz='US/Central')).unique()
Out[3]:
<DatetimeArrayMixin>
['2000-01-01 00:00:00-06:00', '2000-01-02 00:00:00-06:00']
Length: 2, dtype: datetime64[ns, US/Central]
```
